close_symbols: pages[].handler (all handler functions referenced by pages)
explanation:
To decide whether create_response violates the MISRA rule banning direct or indirect recursion we must be able to follow every call edge out of create_response and then transitively follow callees to see if any path returns to create_response. The next agent needs the following symbols so it can build that transitive call graph and detect any path back to create_response:

- MHD_create_post_processor: called directly by create_response; its body/callees could call back into create_response.
- MHD_lookup_connection_value_n, MHD_str_equal_caseless_n_: immediate callees of MHD_create_post_processor; required to continue the transitive analysis from MHD_create_post_processor.
- get_session: called directly by create_response; must inspect its callees for potential paths back.
- MHD_lookup_connection_value: callee of get_session; include to follow the chain.
- MHD_post_process: called directly when handling POST; it may call into other modules that could call back into create_response.
- post_process_urlencoded, post_process_multipart: callees of MHD_post_process; include to continue the transitive closure from MHD_post_process.
- MHD_destroy_post_processor: called when POST processing finishes; its callees could create a path back.
- free_unmarked: callee of MHD_destroy_post_processor; included to continue the chain.
- MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static: used to construct the error response; its implementation may call other helpers that could recurse.
- MHD_create_response_from_buffer_with_free_callback_cls: callee of the above; include to follow further.
- MHD_queue_response: enqueues the response and calls helpers; these helpers could eventually call create_response.
- MHD_DLOG, is_reply_body_needed, MHD_increment_response_rc, MHD_connection_handle_idle, MHD_update_last_activity_: callees of MHD_queue_response; required to explore all outgoing edges from MHD_queue_response.
- MHD_destroy_response: called after queuing; include its callees (if any) to check for recursion.
- pages (the global pages array) and pages[].handler (all handler functions referenced by that array): create_response dispatches to pages[i].handler for GET/HEAD. Any handler can call create_response (directly or indirectly), so all handler functions referenced by pages must be available to detect recursion via the page-handlers path.
- post_iterator: address of this callback is passed into MHD_create_post_processor. The iterator or callbacks reachable from the post-processor could conceivably invoke code that leads back to create_response; include to be safe when analyzing callback-induced recursion.

(Notes: __builtin_unreachable and constants/macros used by these functions are not useful for call-cycle detection. The list is the minimal set of functions and key data (pages + handlers, post_iterator) required to perform a complete transitive call-path search from create_response and determine whether any path returns to it.)
